1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

1.2   General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

1.3   Summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

1.4   Summary of the Five-Year Accident History

1.5   Summary of the Emergency Response Program

1.6   Planned Changes to Improve Safety



RMP Update April 2020 Summary:  This update is being implemented due to a Management of Change (MOC) involving a Condenser upgrade which is a safety, efficiency and condensing capacity improvement.  While the site's refrigeration process utilizes multiple Condensers, the new Condenser affected compiled Process Safety Information (PSI) and a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed in conjunction with the MOC.  The RMP is being updated and re-submitted according to the RMP rules when such events occur.  



This is the Executive Summary component of the Risk Management Plan for 6th Street Cooling, LLC.  The facility is subject to the Federal Risk Management Program and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (Cal/ARP) in the Level III designation, and the Cal/OSHA Process Safety Management Program (PSM).  The Cal/ARP Program establishes additional state-specific requirements.  Additional state-specific requirements are addressed in an addendum report submitted to the local implementing agency (Department of Toxic Substance Control/Imperial County Certified Unified Program Agency a.k.a. Imperial CUPA).  



USEPA Region IX, the Southern California Cal/OSHA PSM Unit and Imperial CUPA Agency have inspected the facility.  The Holtville Fire Department periodically visits the facility to assure effective emergency response preparation & coordination.  6th Street Cooling strives to maintain good working relationships with these oversight agencies.  



1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The 6th Street Cooling Accide

ntal Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies are simply not to have accidental releases or emergencies.  The Company endeavors to execute this policy through the daily implementation of its Safety Programs.  The Company safety program includes but is not limited to a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The PSM Program is an integrated approach to the safe operation of processes using Regulated Substances and forms the Program Level III Prevention Program component of the RMP.  The PSM Program is specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases, and to deal safely with emergencies if they happen.  It is the primary goal of 6th Street Cooling to protect its employees, visitors and neighbors from harm due to Company operations. With this in mind, the priorities of protection of life, the environment, and then property have been established.  Only when these goals are achieved may the focus shift to resumption of business operations.



6th Street Cooling has adopted a "non-responding facility" policy but recognizes the need to be prepared for an emergency.  A California Hazardous Material Business Plan has been developed and submitted to the local Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) via the CA Electronic Reporting System (CERS).  The Plan is consistent with Emergency Action Plan requirements and includes written regulatory release or threatened release notification requirements.  The Business Plan includes the Hazardous Material Inventory consistent with EPCRA compliance in California, and the information necessary to be included in the Area Emergency Plan.  An Emergency Coordinator has been established.   Emergency response pre-planning is coordinated and kept current through the annual submittal of appropriate reports; and relationships with the aforementioned Holtville City Fire & DTSC/CUPA.  The Fire Department has attended Process Hazard Analysis (PHA's) which provides a comprehensive Overview of the Process.  A g

ood working relationship has been established and local response capabilities have been verified.  



6th Street Cooling policy includes maintaining appropriate technical capabilities and to deal with incidental releases (as defined by OSHA) safely if they happen.  Policy also includes qualifying key employees to use Negative Pressure Respirators and attend 1910.120(q) Emergency training.  This policy is to support Public Responders with appropriate technical resources in the event of an ammonia emergency.



1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



6th Street Cooling, LLC is a California Limited Liability (LLC) Company made up of Western Precooling Systems - 50% and Saikhon Family LLC - 50%.  The 6th Street Cooling, LLC is responsible for operations at the site.



6th Street Cooling is a seasonally operated fresh produce refrigeration plant located in Holtville, CA.  Harvest & cooling periods normally begin in early November and conclude in late June each year.  The facility provides refrigeration effect for the removal of field heat from freshly harvested produce and subsequent short-term refrigerated storage until the produce is shipped.  The Plant's stationary refrigeration system is supported with portable refrigeration equipment during peak periods.  General maintenance is year-round, with major maintenance occurring in the off-season summer months.



The Regulated Substance in use is anhydrous ammonia (NH3).  Refrigerating equipment consists of Portable Compressing Units, HydroVac™ Vacuum Tubes, Ice-making equipment & Pressure Cooling Equipment.  Stationary equipment includes a Condenser, Pressure Vessels, Cold Storage Room Evaporators and associated controls, valves, instrumentation and piping.



Vacuum tubes and Pressure Coolers are used to pre-cool agricultural product; the refrigerated storage portion of the facility is used for short-term product storage.  Evaporators (Room Units) in the storage sections of t

he facility maintain temperature until product is sold and shipped.  The refrigeration system is configured in a closed-loop system with isolation and overpressure relief valves installed in key areas. An ammonia-water diffusion system protects against accidental releases from High-Side Pressure Relief Valves.  Refrigerated storage space is monitored with ammonia sensors and an automated alarm system.  



6th Street Cooling, LLC is supported by an affiliate company, Western Precooling Systems (WPS).  WPS is a statewide and well-known provider of ammonia refrigeration equipment and maintenance services.  WPS supports 6th Street Cooling, LLC from its Yuma Operations Office.  Key WPS employees are 1910.120(q) trained and are an additional resource in the event of an emergency. 

   

1.3 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



Accidental Release Prevention Program



A comprehensive Process Safety Management Program (PSM) has been established in accordance with CCR 8, 5189, and is integrated to the Level 3 Prevention Program component of the RMP.  The PSM Program is specifically intended to promote the safe operation of ammonia-handling equipment and process, and to prevent accidental releases.  6th Street Cooling, LLC strives to make the PSM Program an integral part of daily Plant operation.  Other safety programs are integrated with the PSM Program, to the extent practicable and appropriate.  The written PSM document is maintained in the site's RMP binder and/or electronically via the "Web-Based Business Manager" (WBBM); which is an online RMP/PSM/Cal-ARP management solution.



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Over the years it had become apparent in the industry that a mishap while draining oil from the system was historically one of the most common incidents to occur.  Special self-closing valves are now installed as a permissive for oil drain flow in order to mitigate this issue.  If a release were to develop

during an oil-draining task, the mechanic simply releases the handle of the self-closing valve and flow is terminated.  The facility has installed these types of valves at the designated oil drain points.  Other release prevention measures include:



 - Entrance to the facility is closely controlled & monitored

 - A sign-in / sign-out program is established; only authorized personnel are allowed access to process          areas

 - The facility is enclosed with fencing & gates and configured to discourage access by un-authorized personnel

 - Employees are trained for hazard communication (discovery and communicating) for releases, fires, vandals, etc.  Training is documented in each employees training record file. 

 - Personnel are trained in the benefits of good housekeeping.  There is a staff to maintain the general appearance of the facility on a day-to-day basis and limit the accumulation of combustible detritus.

 - Only qualified personnel operate or perform work on the process

 - The facility is manned while in operation  

 - Appropriate automatic safety cut-outs are installed on process equipment

 - Safety cut-outs are regularly inspected and tested

 - A Diffusion system prevents accidental Pressure Relief Valve lifts from releasing directly to the atmosphere (ammonia would be absorbed in water).

 - Pressure Relief Valves are on a 5-Year replacement schedule  

 - Traffic Patterns, Barriers and Equipment Placement have been evaluated and established to prevent vehicular collisions

 - Seismic retrofits and bracing are installed 

 - Off-season ammonia storage is protected with an automated evaporative cooling system (reduces   pressure during sustained seasonal hot spells)



1.4 Five-Year Accident History



There is no data to report.  



1.5 The Emergency Response Program
